Prehistory is the period of time before written records existed. It spans from the emergence of the first humans to the development of writing, roughly 2.5 million to 4,000 years ago. During this time, early humans developed tools, hunted for food, and formed social structures. The discovery of fossils, artifacts, and other archaeological evidence has allowed us to reconstruct a partial picture of prehistoric life. This period is often divided into several distinct periods, including the Paleolithic, Mesolithic, and Neolithic, each characterized by significant technological and cultural advancements. Understanding prehistory helps us grasp the evolution of human societies.

Prehistory is the period of time before written records began. This era is often divided into three main stages: the Paleolithic, Mesolithic, and Neolithic. During the Paleolithic era, early humans lived in small groups and survived by hunting and gathering. The Mesolithic era saw the development of more complex societies and the beginning of settled agriculture. The Neolithic era marked the beginning of domestication of animals and the development of more sophisticated tools. Prehistory is significant because it helps us understand how humans evolved and developed complex societies over time. It also provides valuable insights into early human cultures and ways of life.  -- Source:  https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prehistory  (CC BY-SA 3.0) --
